image.altText: A woman walks past "vote yes" and "vote no" signs on a fence.

items.synopsis: The nation is bound for the ballot box today to cast their vote in a referendum that could shape the country for generations to come — but the path to this poll has been a rocky one.

title.children: A moment decades in the making: It's time for Australians to cast their votes on a new Voice

image.altText: An illustration showing a hand putting a slip of paper into a ballot box, with an Indigenous artwork as a background.

items.synopsis: Australians across the country are heading to the polls to vote in the Voice to Parliament referendum. Follow our live blog for the latest updates.

title.children: Australians head to the polls to cast their vote in Voice to Parliament referendum

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Polling centres have just opened for people in some eastern states to cast their vote in this year's Voice to Parliament Referendum — with millions expected to vote in person. First votes are being put into ballot boxes marking the first official hour of voting day — as people flock to thousands of voting centres across the state. Both Yes and No campaigners are handing out flyers and speaking with voters queuing up outside voting centres, however campaigning is not allowed inside or within six metres of entrances. Out in Melbourne's north at the Northern School for Autism in Reservoir, voters are turning up in droves to cast their referendum vote. The state is waiting to see which way Victoria will swing, with more than 50 per cent of Victorians expected to vote in person today. As the sun rises over Redfern, Sydneysiders line up early to cast their votes. Official Yes campaigner Franz has arrived early to a polling booth, in Sydney. "It's going to be tough, but we just have to hope for the best," he says. Polls open at 8am in your local timezone.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: People across Australia line up early to cast their vote

children.content: Polling centres have just opened for people in some eastern states
to cast their vote in this year's Voice to Parliament Referendum
— with millions expected to vote in person.
First votes are being put into ballot boxes marking the first official hour of voting day — as people flock to thousands of voting centres across the state.
Both Yes and No campaigners are handing out flyers and speaking with voters queuing up outside voting centres, however campaigning is not allowed inside or within six metres of entrances.

Out in Melbourne's north at the Northern School for Autism in Reservoir, voters are turning up in droves to cast their referendum vote. The state is waiting to see which way Victoria will swing, with more than 50 per cent of Victorians expected to vote in person today.
As the sun rises over Redfern, Sydneysiders line up early to cast their votes.

props.alt: A group of people walking as the sun comes up.

children.content: Redfern residents woke up early to cast their votes.
(ABC News: Keana Naughton)
Official Yes campaigner Franz has arrived early to a polling booth, in Sydney.
"It's going to be tough, but we just have to hope for the best," he says.
Polls open at 8am in your local timezone.

props.alt: A picture of a man smiling while wearing a t-shirt.

children.content: Franz has gotten up early to cast his vote.
(ABC News: Keana Naughton)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's been 24 years since Australia held a constitutional referendum, and if you're aged under 42, you won't have ever voted in one before. There are a lot of similarities with elections, but a few key differences that mean referendum night will look a little different. Here's what to expect when polls close in the Voice to Parliament referendum and the counting begins tonight.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How will we know if the referendum passes or fails?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's referendum day! We will be bringing you the latest developments on the Voice to Parliament referendum as they happen today. Voting opens from 8am and closes at 6pm today. Those timings are according to the time zone of the state or territory you're in. Follow along as we bring you live updates throughout the day and into the night.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Welcome to our live coverage

children.content: It's referendum day!

Those timings are according to the time zone of the state or territory you're in.
Follow along as we bring you live updates throughout the day and into the night.

image.altText: A person in a crowd holds up a sign with the Aboriginal flag and the words "Voice to Parliament".

items.synopsis: A No vote — and how we got to one — will change the way we see ourselves, and send the most unloving of messages to Indigenous Australians, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: A prediction made 12 months ago is coming true — and it's sending a painful message

image.altText: Israeli soldiers walk on grassy terrain.

items.synopsis: Israel says its infantry and tanks have carried out raids inside the Gaza Strip, its first announcement of a shift from an air war to ground operations to root out Hamas militants a week after their deadly rampage in southern Israel.

title.children: Israeli military says troops have made their first ground raids into Gaza

image.altText: Two young men are silhouetted on a city street as they walk beside flames burning on the ground after a protest.

items.synopsis: Israeli ground forces have made raids into Gaza over the past 24 hours, the military says, ahead of an expected ground offensive on the densely populated Palestinian territory.

title.children: Middle East on a knife's edge as Israeli ground invasion of Gaza looms

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reuters is reporting that one of its news videographers, Issam Abdallah, was killed on Friday while working in southern Lebanon. The news agency says it is seeking more information and working with the authorities in the region. Earlier, Reuters reported that Israeli shelling had struck a Lebanese army observation post at the border. The Israeli military said it fired in response to a suspected armed infiltration, which it later said had been a false alarm. Israel's UN envoy, Gilad Erdan, said it would investigate what had happened in the area following the journalist's death. "We always try to mitigate and avoid civilian casualties. Obviously, we would never want to hit or kill or shoot any journalist that is doing its job," Mr Erdan said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reuters journalist killed in southern Lebanon

children.content: Reuters is reporting that one of its news videographers, Issam Abdallah, was killed on Friday while working in southern Lebanon.
The news agency says it is seeking more information and working with the authorities in the region.

props.alt: A middle-aged man with a beard, sunglasses and camera stands on a ruined city street, looking at the camera.

children.content: Issam Abdallah takes a selfie while working in Turkey in February.
(Reuters)
Earlier, Reuters reported that Israeli shelling had struck a Lebanese army observation post at the border.
The Israeli military said it fired in response to a suspected armed infiltration, which it later said had been a false alarm.
Israel's UN envoy, Gilad Erdan, said it would investigate what had happened in the area following the journalist's death.
"We always try to mitigate and avoid civilian casualties. Obviously, we would never want to hit or kill or shoot any journalist that is doing its job," Mr Erdan said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Palestinians have been fleeing south from Gaza City and nearby towns after Israel issued its warning to civilians to evacuate northern Gaza on Friday. About half the tiny territory's population lives in the north, meaning Israel's warning affects roughly 1.1 million people. Hamas has urged Gazans not to comply with Israel's evacuation order, but the Associated Press reports it has not made any attempts to prevent the mass exodus. Men, women and children could be seen packed together on the back of trucks and bikes along with household possessions as long lines of vehicles stretched out of the territory's capital.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Palestinians flee northern Gaza ahead of Israeli deadline

children.content: Palestinians have been fleeing south from Gaza City and nearby towns after Israel issued its warning to civilians to evacuate northern Gaza on Friday.
About half the tiny territory's population lives in the north, meaning Israel's warning affects roughly 1.1 million people.

props.alt: A city street is packed with cars as smoke rises from buildings in the background.

children.content: Palestinian civilians flee Gaza City on Friday after Israel's warning.
(AP Photo)
Hamas has urged Gazans not to comply with Israel's evacuation order, but the Associated Press reports it has not made any attempts to prevent the mass exodus.
Men, women and children could be seen packed together on the back of trucks and bikes along with household possessions as long lines of vehicles stretched out of the territory's capital.

props.alt: Palestinian men, women and children packed into the back of trucks in a traffic jam.

children.content: Civilians had little warning to evacuate northern Gaza.
(AP Photo)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The IDF says Israeli ground forces have conducted raids in the Gaza Strip over the past 24 hours, ahead of its expected ground offensive. A statement from the army said it had conducted the "localised" raids to "complete the effort to cleanse the area of terrorists and weaponry", as well as to attempt to find missing people. Hamas militants abducted an estimated 150 Israelis and foreigners during their terror attack in southern Israel last weekend. Read the full story below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli troops conduct early ground raids into Gaza

featuredLink.title: Israeli military says troops have made their first ground raids into Gaza

props.alt: Two soldiers jog on a street as a large armoured vehicle kicks up dust in the background.

children.content: An Israeli armoured personnel carrier drives near the Gaza border on Friday.
(Reuters)
The IDF says Israeli ground forces have conducted raids in the Gaza Strip over the past 24 hours, ahead of its expected ground offensive.
A statement from the army said it had conducted the "localised" raids to "complete the effort to cleanse the area of terrorists and weaponry", as well as to attempt to find missing people.
Hamas militants abducted an estimated 150 Israelis and foreigners during their terror attack in southern Israel last weekend.
Read the full story below.

image.altText: Three posters with photographs of people and the words 'bring them home'

items.synopsis: A week after Hamas terrorists' brutal attack on Israel, up to 150 kidnap victims remain in Gaza. Experts on hostage negotiation and terrorism say the world now faces several difficult choices.

title.children: The world's never seen a hostage crisis quite like this. Here's how it could play out

image.altText: A woman sobs as people stand against a sandstone wall at a funeral

items.synopsis: Israel is preparing to carry out a ground operation whose mission is to "destroy Hamas". But what then? What is the political reality and make-up of Gaza and what would it look like without Hamas, asks John Lyons.

title.children: 'Israel now will not stop': One week into war and a dangerous political reality has set in

image.altText: Girl with Star of David painted on her cheek sits on a man's shoulders waving Israeli flag

items.synopsis: There are heightened fears in Victoria's Jewish community of a wave of anti-Semitic sentiment as the Israel-Gaza conflict escalates.

title.children: Victoria's Jewish community encouraged not to fear and not to hide 'Jewishness'

image.altText: A sullen man looks into the camera.

items.synopsis: There was a time when the name of one whistleblower was on everyone's lips. Kathy Jackson was lauded as a "revolutionary" — but in the shadows was another person waiting to blow the whistle on her.

title.children: The whistleblower who captured the nation — and the man who unmasked her as a fraud

image.altText: A man in a suit, sitting for an interview with a microphone clipped to his tie.

items.synopsis: In 2021, a doctor and pastor met with his friends in Florida allegedly to arrange the overthrow of the Haitian president. Now Kenya is being sent in to help a country plunged into chaos.

title.children: How a group of Florida men allegedly plotted the assassination of the Haitian president and sent the country into chaos

image.altText: Costa, who has long hair and a bushy beard, smiles against a blue backdrop, with images of a cheese toastie and kimchi.

items.synopsis: If we're being honest, Costa's known for one thing: the delightfully enormous beard covering half his face. We sat down with the Gardening Australia host to find out if his big beard really is full of secrets.

title.children: Eating burgers with a knife and fork and even killing houseplants: Costa reveals his darkest secrets

image.altText: Victoria Beckham and David Beckham pose for a photo, wearing suits, in front of a Netflix media wall

items.synopsis: The Posh and Becks story is a distortion of the Cinderella legend, as triumph isn't the result of noblesse oblige, of being selected, but the result of middle class striving that Britain has long struggled to understand, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: As Posh and Becks became more successful, the invisible class wall was always there

image.altText: composite of fire truck for western australia fire service, people at a beach side pool in sydney and people skiing in perisher

items.synopsis: A quick glance at the national forecast this weekend and you could be forgiven for questioning what season we're in. ABC meteorologist Tom Saunders explains what is driving the country's weather disparity.

title.children: Fire and ice – why is spring weather so changeable?

image.altText: England's Ollie Watkins slides in to score a goal against the Socceroos.

items.synopsis: The Socceroos are unable to replicate the famous upset win from 20 years ago, going down 1-0 after a second-half Ollie Watkins strike.

title.children: Socceroos go down to England in Wembley friendly

image.altText: A Cruise driverless taxi in San Francisco

items.synopsis: A recent Californian trial saw self-driving taxis crash into a fire truck and get bogged in wet cement. Such incidents erode trust in the technology, writes autonomous systems researcher Zena Assaad.

title.children: The dream of driverless cars may have hit a roadblock — public trust

image.altText: Yes and No graphic for Voice to Parliament.

items.synopsis: Yes and No camps have run their respective campaign races but if you blinked and missed it, here's what you need to know about each case.

title.children: Making your mind up today? The Yes and No cases for the Voice explained

items.synopsis: Here’s what to expect when polls close in the Voice to Parliament referendum and the counting begins tonight.

title.children: How will we know if the Referendum passes or fails?

image.altText: Sensors sit next to a tablet with weather information

items.synopsis: Queensland researchers launch a project to develop an in-home early warning system for elderly residents during extreme heat.

title.children: They might not look like much, but these little sensors could save lives as Australian summers get hotter

image.altText: In the golden light of a dusty evening, is a silhouette of man in hat on horseback leading cattle.

items.synopsis: Bullo River Station on the edge of the east Kimberley is a cattle station with its gaze firmly fixed on nature. Working with the Australian Wildlife Conservancy, they are demonstrating conservation and pastoral activities can coexist.

title.children: As a place for big dreams, this Kimberley cattle station shows how conservation and pastoral goals can combine

image.altText: A young woman gazes at a magenta flower

items.synopsis: When Lauren Bouyer tries to conjure an image in her mind's eye, nothing happens. Researchers say her condition, aphantasia, is more prevalent than previously thought.

title.children: Loren can't 'see' things in her imagination. It's more common than you might think

image.altText: a woman wearing a stripey shirt standing outside.

items.synopsis: Before last week's bushfire hit, the Binney family planned to operate their newly purchased cabins in Gippsland as an accommodation business. Now they face an uncertain future on several fronts.

title.children: Fire-affected families grapple with prospect of rebuilding in bushfire-prone area

image.altText: A man wearing a suit sits on a stool surrounded by TV camera and lights.

items.synopsis: Anxiety about coming out. Name calling. Feeling you can't be your true self at work. Three LGBTQIA+ journalists discuss some of the hurdles they've experienced in their careers.

title.children: In The Newsreader, a journalist is threatened with being outed. It happened to Anton Enus in real life

image.altText: a ballot paper is dropping in a sealed ballot box with a purple lid

items.synopsis: Today, millions will go to the polling booths to cast their votes in the Voice to Parliament referendum. Let's cover the basics before you get into the booth.

title.children: Your guide to today's Voice to Parliament vote

image.altText: A composite photo of Ramia Abdo Sultan, left, and Tzipi Cohen Hyams, both looking serious

items.synopsis: Many Israeli and Palestinian people in Australia know someone who has either been killed, injured, kidnapped, displaced, or is in hiding. As the conflict escalates, they fear more bad news.

title.children: 'I fear what's going to happen next': Israelis and Palestinians in Australia reflect on the week that changed everything

image.altText: A woman wearing yellow and blue holds a soccer ball to her chest with a window in the background

items.synopsis: Returning to her first professional club Central Coast Mariners, the Matildas forward is ready to answer her critics.

title.children: Kyah Simon wants to banish her Women's World Cup ghosts

image.altText: Vanessa Amorosi wears a black jacket and pants and brown top and holds a black bag as she walks behind a white car.

items.synopsis: Australian singer-songwriter Vanessa Amorosi has denied deliberately making a false statement to authorities, having a bad memory, and trying to win a legal case against her mother because she was short of money.

title.children: 'You guys are … disgusting': Emails between Vanessa Amorosi and her mother shown to court during civil trial

image.altText: A woman walking along a pathway

items.synopsis: Seven people have been diagnosed with colorectal cancer after Albury Wodonga health authorities conducted nearly 1,100 repeat colonoscopies for patients who received defective treatment from surgeon Dr Liu-Ming Schmidt.

title.children: Hospital apologises after seven people diagnosed with cancer following colonoscopy recall

image.altText: Melbourne federal court building with federal court signage in foreground

items.synopsis: The Victorian Farming Federation revealed in the Federal Court that there was no mechanism in its constitution to remove its president, a situation the judge suggested sounded "pretty undemocratic".

title.children: Federal Court denies injunction for farmers seeking to remove Victoria's peak farming body president

image.altText: A woman, a man and two young children look at the camera, surrounded by luggage and other people

items.synopsis: Tal Raymond, Dana Elhadad and their two young children were among the first Australians at Tel Aviv's Ben Gurion Airport for a Qantas repatriation flight on Friday, but not all of them got on board.

title.children: 'Hardest decision I've ever had to make': Aussie families torn apart at Tel Aviv airport

image.altText: A composite image of buildings with smoke behind them and a young girl speaking

items.synopsis: Palestinians say they are living in a "constant state of fear" as Gaza residents continue to struggle with no power and a dwindling food supply.

title.children: 'I doubt I will make it out alive': Gazans say they feel 'trapped in a cage' and 'waiting for death'

image.altText: three men walk out of the kings cross police station after they were arrested for allegedly doing the nazi salute

items.synopsis: The men, aged 30, 31 and 40, are charged under new laws over the public display of Nazi flags and memorabilia banned across the state last year.

title.children: Three men charged over alleged Nazi salute outside Sydney Jewish Museum

image.altText: The outside of the Toowoomba Court

items.synopsis: The identity of a high-profile man accused of rape in Toowoomba will remain a secret for now despite a court denying the man a non-publication order.

title.children: Identity of high-profile man accused of rape in Toowoomba will remain secret

image.altText: An animation of a spacecraft approaching an asteroid in space.

items.synopsis: The Psyche probe, folded inside the cargo bay of a SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket is due to reach the asteroid in August 2029.

title.children: NASA launches spacecraft to explore metal-rich asteroid believed to be worth $US10 quadrillion

image.altText: A portrait of a woman with long dark hair wearing a black top.

items.synopsis: Karinda Taylor runs an Aboriginal-led health service, where short election cycles make it difficult to secure long-term funding. She believes the Voice could help achieve generational change.

title.children: Karinda lost her father to a preventable disease when she was 14. Now she works to save lives in her community

image.altText: A map of Australia electorates divided between orange and purple.

items.synopsis: The rules that determine how the Voice referendum will be run were written more than 100 years ago.

title.children: In referendums, not all votes are created equal
